page_analysis.text_content:
Contextual front setbacks

Contextual setbacks apply if, and only if, the average of the existing setbacks on the same side of the block is 30' or greater.

How to determine if a contextual setback applies using Fig 15 below, as an example.

Does block have more than 3 lots? (incl project lot)

Note: If block is more than 600' long, consider only lots within 600' (max. 10 lots).

Yes Exclude the following types of lots:
  • Flag lot (C)
  • Multi-family use w/ 3+ units (G)
  • Corner lot facing cross street (H)

Is the number of remaining lots more or less than 5 or more?

Yes Exclude the smallest and largest setbacks:
  • Smallest (D)
  • Largest (E)

Find the average of the remaining lots (incl. subject lot). If greater than 30', it applies.

30 (A)
33 (B)
+ 35 (F)
98 ÷ 3 = 32.7

Fig 15 Example of a block with a contextual setback of 32.7'

visual_elements.description: Flowchart showing decision steps to determine if a contextual setback applies. It starts with the question 'Does block have more than 3 lots? (incl project lot)'. If yes, exclude certain lot types (Flag lot (C), Multi-family use with 3+ units (G), Corner lot facing cross street (H)). Then check if the number of remaining lots is 5 or more. If yes, exclude the smallest (D) and largest (E) setbacks. Finally, find the average of the remaining lots including the subject lot. If the average is greater than 30', the contextual setback applies. The example calculation shows 30 (A) + 33 (B) + 35 (F) = 98 ÷ 3 = 32.7.

Fig 15 is a block diagram illustrating lots labeled A through H with various lot types and setbacks. Lots A, B, D, E, F are Single-Family; C is a Flag lot; G is Multi-family (3+ units); H is a corner lot facing another street. Setbacks are indicated with measurements: 30' (A), 33' (B), 20' (D), 37' (E), 35' (F), and 'no' for G and H. The diagram includes lot lines, sidewalks, curbs, buildable areas (dashed), existing houses (solid black), and required setbacks (dashed lines). The diagram visually excludes lots C, G, and H from the average setback calculation.

technical_specifications.parameter: Minimum average existing setbacks on same side of block for contextual setbacks to apply
Maximum block length considered for lots in calculation
Maximum number of lots considered if block is longer than 600'
Example setbacks for lots A, B, D, E, F
Calculated average contextual setback in example
